description: From Middle English blasfemen, blasphemen, from Old French blasfemer, from Ecclesiastical Latin blasphēmō, from Ancient Greek βλασφημέω (blasphēméō). Doublet of blame.

verbs.description: blaspheme (third-person singular simple present blasphemes, present participle blaspheming, simple past and past participle blasphemed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To commit blasphemy; to speak against God or religious doctrine.
examples: Mrs. Murphy: Don't you blaspheme in here!

entries.meaning: (transitive) To speak of, or address, with impious irreverence; to revile impiously (anything sacred).
examples: How long, O Lord, holy and true, dost thou not judge and avenge thyself on all those who thus continually blaspheme thy great and all-glorious name?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To calumniate; to revile; to abuse.
